Graphical abstract Selective oxidation of secondary alcohols to ketones using tert-butyl hydroperoxide was accomplished over active and reusable silver incorporated octahedral molecular sieve (Ag-OMS-2) catalyst. Different loadings of Ag (5â15% w/w) were incorporated in OMS-2 by the precipitation method among which 15% w/w Ag-OMS-2 was found to be the best. The catalyst was fully characterized. It possesses nanofibrous crystalline structure with high surface area. Oxidation of 1-phenylethanol, as a model compound, was conducted at 75Â°C into acetophenone by tert-butyl hydroperoxide over 15% w/w Ag-OMS-2. Effects of various parameters were investigated in detail. A mathematical model is built to interpret the experimental data and develop mechanism. The reaction is intrinsically kinetically controlled and follows second order kinetics. The modeling will help reactor design and scale-up. As an extension to the studies, oxidation of various aliphatic and aromatic alcohols was studied in the liquid phase over 15% w/w Ag-OMS-2 catalyst under optimized conditions. The catalyst is reusable up-to five runs without any loss in catalytic activity. The results obtained are novel. Aldehydes or ketones, as well as carboxylic acids, find wide applications in a variety of processes and products in the pharmaceutical, agrochemical, vitamin, and perfumery industries [2]. However, oxidations are carried out by using polluting and hazardous oxidizing agents leading to high environmental factor (E-factor) and generation of large amounts of toxic waste [3]. Conventionally oxidation is carried out using stoichiometric amount of reagents such as chromic acid, permanganate, and ruthenium or nitrogen oxide with nitric acid, which produces environmentally deleterious heavy metal waste [4â8]. Many halogen-containing oxidizing reagents and supported metal ions are reported for the oxidation of various aromatic and aliphatic substrates [9â27]. These methods are beset with several drawbacks such as use of expensive metal catalysts, severe reaction conditions and incompatible oxidizing agent [28]. Hence there is a tremendous scope to design and develop new catalytic oxidation processes which are safer, greener and economical. Recently Chen et al. [29] have reported advantage of ionic liquid as an additive in carbon nanotube supported palladium catalyzed aerobic oxidation of 1-phenylethanol; however, the reaction was carried out at very high temperature. Efforts are underway in many laboratories to develop novel catalysts which are tolerable to various functional groups and selectively able to oxidize the desired moiety. Selectivity engineering of catalytic process is the need of modern chemical industry to reduce waste minimization. Yadav and Manyar [30] have reported synthesis, characterization and application of a novel V-OMS-2 based redox catalyst UDCaT-3 in selective oxidation, hydroxylation and hydrogenation reactions including mecapto compounds [31]. Octahedral molecular sieves (OMS) have been reportedly used for dehydration reactions. Further, OMS-2 having 2Ã2 tunnel structure doped with active metal or combination of metals is recently reported for reduction of acetophenone to 1-phenylethanol by Yadav and Mewada [32]. OMS and Octahedral layered (OL) materials based on porous mixed-valent manganese oxides are potentially useful catalysts due to their unique properties such as excellent semi-conductivity, particle size and porosity [33â35]. Catalytic properties of OMS and OL materials have been ascribed to the redox cycling of different oxidations states of manganese such as Mn2+, Mn3+, and Mn4+. The smaller pore opening is possibly responsible higher stability of OMS-2. It is reported that OMS-2 has better stability than OMS-1 materials [36]. The occurrence of counter cations such as alkali and alkaline earth metals and water is shown to be the cause for the stability and charge balance on structure of OMS-2. Inclusion of metals in the tunnel structure leads to increase in defects inside the catalyst surface thereby creating more number of active sites [30,32,37]. Our laboratory has reported hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1, 2-propanediol over 30% w/w Ag-OMS-2 as an excellent catalyst [38]. Selective hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to azobenzene over nano-fibrous Ag-OMS-2 is also reported [39]. Recently application of costly gold nanoparticle and N-hydroxyphthaliminde in ionic liquid was reported, which involves formation of undesired products and long reaction time [40]. The current work describes the use of nano-fibrous Ag-OMS-2 as the catalyst for the oxidation of various secondary aliphatic and aromatic alcohols to ketones. We have carried out both batch and continuous mode of operations to determine stability of the catalyst. Different loadings of Ag on OMS-2 were incorporated by the precipitation method. This paper reports a comprehensive account of this catalytic process. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals All chemicals were procured from reputed firms and used without further purification. 1-Phenylethanol, benzhydrol, 2-hydroxy-1-phenylethanol, 4-hydroxy-1-phenylethanol, 4-methoxy1-phenylethanol, 4-chloro-1-phenylethanol, 3-methyl-1-phenylethanol, potassium permanganate, silver nitrate, 2-propanol and nitric acid (70% w/v) were purchased from M/s s.d. Fine Chem Ltd., Mumbai, India. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis Ag doped manganese oxide octahedral molecular sieves (OMS-2) was synthesized by precipitation method as follows [13]. Manganese acetate (21.0g) was dissolved in 67.5cm3 deionised water and then concentrated nitric acid was added. Silver nitrate (9.97g) was dissolved in 50cm3 distilled water and added to acidic manganese acetate at 30Â°C. KMnO4 (13.3g) was taken in 275cm3 distilled water and added to the above solution dropwise at 70Â°C and the black precipitate so obtained was agitated and refluxed at 100Â°C for 24h. The precipitate was washed several times with deionised water to pH of 7. The resulting material was filtered and dried at 120Â°C for 12h to obtain 15% w/w Ag-OMS-2 [32,37,38]. These catalysts have typical cryptomelane structure with a one-dimensional 2Ã2 channel structure. 2.3 Experimental setup All experiments were conducted in 50cm3 glass reactor. A four bladedâpitched turbine impeller was used for reaction. The temperature was maintained at the selected value. Weighed quantities of reactants and catalyst were charged to the reactor and then the temperature raised to the desired value. Thereafter the agitation was commenced. An initial sample was taken and further sampling was done periodically up to 4h. A standard experiment was performed with 0.01mol 1-phenylethanol, 0.03mol TBHP and catalyst quantity of 0.012g/cm3. The temperature was normally maintained at 75Â°C at 900rpm as speed of agitation. The total volume of liquid phase was 15.0cm3 in which 0.2cm3 n-decane was used as internal standard. At the end of experiment, the catalyst was filtered and the organic layer was concentrated and purified by column chromatography. 2.4 Method of analysis Clear liquid samples of reaction mass were analyzed by GC (Chemito, model 1000) using FID and a capillary wax column BP-20 (0.25mm diameter and 30m length). The product was confirmed by GCâMS (Perkin Elmer instrument, Clarus 500) with BP-1 capillary column (0.25mm i.d., 30m length) and EI mode of MS. The injector and detector temperatures were maintained at 220Â°C. The oven temperature was programmed from 90Â°C to 220Â°C, with a ramp rate of 15Â°C/min. Nitrogen was employed as the carrier gas at a flow rate of 0.5cm3/s. The quantification of data was based on the disappearance of the limiting reactant. The products were also confirmed by GCâMS. 2.5 Reaction scheme Oxidation of 1-phenylethanol using 15% w/w Ag-OMS-2 is given by Scheme 1 . In this reaction 1-butanol is the co-product along with water. The alcohol can be recycled. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization Ag-OMS-2 was characterized by various techniques such as SEM, TEM, ammonia-TPD, XRD, BET surface area, FTIR and elemental analysis and more details have been published recently by our group [32,37,38]. Only a few prominent features are presented here to put the current studies in perspective. The catalyst was nano-fibrous and nano-crystalline as revealed by SEM (Fig. 1 ) and TEM (Fig. 2 ). The TEM also showed a fibrous nano-rod shaped structure. Replacement of K ions with Ag ions inside the tunnel framework is confirmed by EDX [32,37]. The difference in physical and chemical properties of metal cation dopants was responsible for their content in OMS structure during synthesis. As a consequence, all metal cations have variations in their theoretical and actual compositions. For 15% w/w Ag-OMS-2 synthesis, almost 15% Ag ions were retained in the catalyst. The size of Ag+, which is smaller than K+, is favorable to fit into the 4.6Ã tunnel of OMS-2 and also more surface area than parent OMS-2. TPD analysis of 15% w/w Ag-OMS-2 with ammonia and carbon dioxide as probe molecule confirmed the existence of mild acidic and basic sites, respectively [32,37,38]. Incorporation of silver into OMS-2 resulted in strong interaction of silver with OMS surface leading to a drastic decrease in reduction temperature from 280Â°C of K-OMS-2 to 162Â°C for 15% w/w Ag-OMS-2, which was revealed by TPR. The XRD of K-OMS-2 and Ag-OMS-2 had revealed well crystalline structure characteristic of octahedral molecular sieve material and the reflections and 2Î¸ values obtained were characteristic of 2Ã2 tunnel structured manganese oxide phase (KMn8O16, JCPDS 34-168) [32,37]. The crystal domain size of cryptomelane phase derived from the XRD peaks broadening was 20nm [32,37]. FT-IR studies showed OMS-2 structure was intact after inclusion of metal in the tunnel framework [32]. The BET surface area, pore volume and pore diameter for 15% w/w Ag-OMS-2 are much better than those for OMS-2. A surface area 118.8m2/g was obtained for 15% w/w Ag-OMS-2 as compared to 89.1m2/g of OMS-2 [32,37,38]. The adsorption-desorption isotherm was type III isotherm, suggesting a porous structure. Such type of adsorption occurs in cases where heats of adsorption are lower than the adsorbate heat of liquefaction. 3.2 Effect of oxidant The rate of activation of reactant is governed by the nature of catalyst, oxidizing agent, and temperature. The effect of various oxidants on liquid phase oxidation of 1-phenylethanol, the model compound, was conducted at 75Â°C. In this case, neither hydrogen peroxide nor air was found to be suitable as oxidizing agent, with no conversion, whereas tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) was effective. A control experiment was also performed in the absence of catalyst to ascertain that the reaction did not proceed without catalyst. 3.3 Activity of various catalysts The efficacies of UDCaT-3 and different Ag-OMS-2 are shown in Fig. 3 . It is evident that incorporation of silver inside the framework of the catalyst enhances the activity of catalyst considerably. Mesoporous redox catalyst UDCaT-3 [30,31] lead to good conversion. A conversion of 45% was achieved in case of K-OMS, which is OMS-2, whereas with increasing Ag content in the OMS-2, there was increase in conversion and yield. There is a synergistic effect of silver in presence of manganese and potassium ions in the catalyst. Further increase in loading of silver ion does not lead to any significant difference in the conversion of oxidation reaction. Hence further experiments were performed with 15% w/w Ag-OMS-2. 3.4 Effect of various solvents The effect of solvent in the liquid phase oxidation of secondary alcohol using TBHP as oxidant is given in Fig. 4 . Solvents such as acetonitrile, toluene, dioxane, DMF and DMSO were screened for the reaction. In case of non-polar solvent like toluene, 75% conversion was achieved, on the other hand, in polar aprotic solvents such as DMF and DMSO conversion of 50% and 27% was obtained, respectively. Acetonitrile was the best solvent under optimized reaction conditions; the results obtained were in accordance with the literature reports on use of acetonitrile. 3.5 Effect of speed of agitation Fig. 5 depicts the effect of speed of agitation on conversion from 700rpm to 1100rpm at 75Â°C at the catalyst loading of 0.012g/cm3 (Fig. 5 ). In the range of 900â1100rpm, the conversion was practically the same. Thus, the external resistance to mass transfer was absent beyond 900rpm. However, to avoid catalyst abrasion and to ensure complete absence of mass transfer resistance, 900rpm was used as minimum speed in further runs. 3.6 Effect of catalyst loading A mole ratio of 1-phenylethanol to TBHP of 1:3 (Fig. 6 ). Both conversion and rate of reaction increased up to 0.012g/cm3 with increase in catalyst loading due to the corresponding increase in active sites. The conversion and rate of reaction were nearly identical at 0.012g/cm3 and 0.015g/cm3. It would suggest that the number of catalyst sites at catalyst loading of 0.015g/cm3was greater than that required by the reacting species. Theoretical calculations using WieszâPrater criterion were also done to show absence of intra-particle resistance [41]. 3.7 Effect of mole ratio The mole ratio of 1-phenylethanol to TBHP was changed from 1:1 to 1:3 with a catalyst loading of 0.012g/cm3 at 75Â°C (Fig. 7 ). The initial rate of the reaction increased with increase in mole ratio. It can be concluded that there was not much difference in the conversions at mole ratios of 1:2 and 1:3. Therefore the next set of reactions were conducted at a mole ratio of 1:3 of 1-phenylethanol to TBHP. 3.8 Effect of temperature The temperature effect on conversion and rate was studied from 65Â°C to 80Â°C (Fig. 8 ). With an increase in temperature the rate of reaction and conversion increased significantly, which indicated that reaction was intrinsically kinetically controlled. This would be discussed later. 3.9 Substrate study To explore the scope and generality of the developed protocol for the oxidation of secondary alcohols using nano-fibrous 15% w/w Ag-OMS-2, oxidation of various alcohols was studied at the same conditions (Table 1 ). Cyclic alcohols like cyclohexanol and cyclopentanol are efficiently oxidized with conversions of 90% and 85%, respectively. Good results were obtained for the oxidation of substituted 1-phenylethanol. It should be recognized that temperature plays a very important role and higher conversions could be obtained at higher temperatures for less reacting molecules. The purpose here was to use the same reaction conditions to understand their reactivity. Selectivity is 100% for the oxidation of secondary alcohols because even though conversion is low, no other product except the ketone was observed. Other groups present in the moiety such as phenolic OH (entry 2 and 4), methyl (entry 6) and methylene (entry 8 and 9) are unaffected under the mild set of conditions used here. 3.10 Development of mechanistic model and kinetics of the reaction The reaction of 1-phenylethanol with TBHP in presence of 15% w/w Ag-OMS-2 gives acetophenone at 75Â°C. It is assumed that reaction follows LangmuirâHinshelwoodâHougenâWatson (LHHW) type mechanism with participation of two sites. Both reacting molecules are adsorbed on active sites and undergo surface reaction to produce acetophenone, tert-butanol and water. The concentration-time profiles of reactants and products confirmed that reactant and products are weakly adsorbed on the surface and get desorbed very fast. Thus, surface reaction of adsorbed species could control the overall rate of reaction. Adsorption of 1-phenylethanol (A) on a vacant site S is given by (1) A + S â· K â² A K A AS Adsorption of TBHP (B) on vacant site S (2) B + S â· K â² B K B BS Surface reaction between AS and BS, in the vicinity of the active site, leading to formation of product âacetophenone (C), tert-Butanol (D), and water (W)â as follows (3) AS + BS + S â¶ k 2 CS + DS + WS Desorption of products from the surface of catalyst: (4) CS â· 1 / k C C + S (5) DS â· 1 / k D D + S (6) WS â· 1 / K W W + S The total concentration of sites, C t given by (7) C t = C S + C AS + C BS + C CS + C DS + C WS (8) C t = C S + K A C A C S + K B C B C S + K C C C C S + K D C D C S + K W C W C S Therefore concentration of vacant site is given by (9) C S = C t 1 + K A C A + K B C B + K C C C + K D C D + K W C W If equation (3) controls the rate of reaction, then the rate of reaction of A is given by (10) r A = â d C A d t = k 2 C AS C BS C S (11) r A = â d C A d t = k 2 K A K B C A C B C S 3 After substituting the value of C S from equation (9) we get (12) â d C A d t = k 2 K A K B C A C B C t 3 ( 1 + K A C A + K B C B + K C C C + K D C D + K W C W ) 3 When the reaction is far away from the equilibrium (13) â d C A d t = k 2 K A K B C A C B C t 3 ( 1 + â K i C i ) 3 (14) â d C A d t = k R 2 w C A C B ( 1 + â K i C i ) 3 where k R 2 w = k 2 K A K B C t 3 and w is catalyst loading. If adsorption and desorption of the species are very weak and values of equilibrium constants are very small then above equation can be given as (15) d C A d t = k R 2 w C A C B Let C Bo/C Ao = M, the molar ratio of 1-phenylethanol at t =0. Then the above equation (16) d X A d t = k R 2 w C Ao ( 1 â X A ) ( M â X A ) (17) d X A d t = k 1 C Ao ( 1 â X A ) ( M â X B ) Integrating above equation (18) ln M â X A M 1 â X A = k 1 C Ao ( M â 1 ) t The plot of ln M â X A / M 1 â X A against t was made at different temperatures, where M =3, to get an excellent fit, thereby supporting the model (Fig. 9 ). This is an overall second order reaction. The apparent energy of activation was calculated by plotting Arrhenius plot as 12.65kcal/mol for oxidation of 1-phenylethanol (Fig. 10 ). 3.11 Reusability of catalyst The reusability of 15% w/w Ag-OMS-2 was tested by conducting 6 runs. After each run the catalyst was filtered and refluxed with 50cm3 of acetonitrile in order to remove any adsorbed material from the catalyst surface, then it was dried in an oven at 120Â°C for 2h. In a typical batch reaction, there was an inevitable loss of particles during filtration due to attrition. The catalyst was reused without any make up quantity and the experiments were done under otherwise similar conditions. The volume of reaction mixture was adjusted to make the catalyst loading of 0.012g/cm3. It was observed that there is only marginal decrease in the conversion (Fig. 11 ). Thus, the catalyst was active and reusable even after six runs for the liquid phase oxidation of secondary alcohols. 4 Conclusion The liquid phase oxidation of various secondary alcohols was carried out using Ag-OMS-2 at 75Â°C with catalyst loading of 0.012g/cm3. TBHP was the most effective oxidizing agent. Addition of silver ion from 5 to 15wt% in the pores of K-OMS significantly improves the redox property of catalyst and 15% w/w Ag-OMS-2 was the most active and selective catalyst. The synergistic effect among Ag, Mn and K ions was responsible for the enhancement in the activity of catalyst. Various parameters affecting the rate of reaction and conversion were discussed in detail. It was found that a mole ratio of 1:3 of alcohol to TBHP, speed of agitation 900rpm, catalyst loading of 0.012g/cm3, and temperature of 75Â°C in acetonitrile were the best conditions to get good activity of catalyst. Increase in temperature can be beneficial for oxidation of the least reactive alcohol since it can provide sufficient energy for higher conversion and rate. A detailed kinetic study was carried out, which indicates that reaction follows LangmuirâHinshelwoodâHougenâWatson type of model with weak adsorption of all species. The apparent energy of activation was found to be 12.65kcal/mol for 1-phenylethanol. The optimized conditions were very effective for oxidation of various alcohols. So the catalyst is tolerable to various functional groups present in the molecule and has given well to excellent conversion for the oxidation reaction of a variety of alcohols. coredata.dc:description: Selective oxidation of secondary alcohols to ketones using tert-butyl hydroperoxide was accomplished over active and reusable silver incorporated octahedral molecular sieve (Ag-OMS-2) catalyst. Different loadings of Ag (5â15% w/w) were incorporated in OMS-2 by the precipitation method among which 15% w/w Ag-OMS-2 was found to be the best. The catalyst was fully characterized. It possesses nanofibrous crystalline structure with high surface area. Oxidation of 1-phenylethanol, as a model compound, was conducted at 75Â°C into acetophenone by tert-butyl hydroperoxide over 15% w/w Ag-OMS-2. Effects of various parameters were investigated in detail. A mathematical model is built to interpret the experimental data and develop mechanism. The reaction is intrinsically kinetically controlled and follows second order kinetics. The modeling will help reactor design and scale-up. As an extension to the studies, oxidation of various aliphatic and aromatic alcohols was studied in the liquid phase over 15% w/w Ag-OMS-2 catalyst under optimized conditions. The catalyst is reusable up-to five runs without any loss in catalytic activity. The results obtained are novel.
coredata.dc:title: Selective liquid phase oxidation of secondary alcohols into ketones by tert-butyl hydroperoxide on nano-fibrous Ag-OMS-2 catalyst
